quote: All beings are the owners of their deeds, the heirs of their deeds; their deeds are the womb from which they sprang; with their deeds they are bound up; their deeds are their refuge. Whatever deeds they do, good or bad, of such they will be the heirs.

In the same way, when one dwells contemplating gratification in things that can fetter, craving increases. From craving, clinging arises. With clinging as condition, existence; with existence as condition, birth; with birth as condition, aging and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair come to be. Such is the origin of this whole mass of suffering.

The thought occurs to me, 'This Dhamma is for one with few desires, not for one with strong desires.' But then it occurs to me, 'Desire is clinging.' With clinging as condition, existence; with existence as condition, birth; with birth as condition, aging and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair come to be. Such is the origin of this whole mass of suffering.
All things are not-self. If one sees this with insight, one becomes disenchanted with dukkha. This is the path to purity.
These two bright principles guard the world; they are reckoned to be the chief among gods: Not to do any evil, to cultivate good, to purify one's mind — this is the teaching of the Buddhas.
The world is burning, the world is aflame, the world is convulsing. The world is not stable, it has no shelter; there is no one in charge. It's swept away by aging and death.
But those who, when taught, take to heart the Dhamma will cross over the realm of Death, so difficult to cross.
For there is no person in the world who is dearer to me than myself. In the same way, there is no person in the world who is dearer to another than himself.
In the past, Bāvarī Vāseṭṭha and Vāseṭṭha the brahmin wandered over and went through all the wrong views, and finally arrived at annihilationism.

There is, bhikkhus, a realm where there is neither earth nor water, nor fire nor air, nor the infinity of space, nor the infinity of consciousness, nor nothingness, nor perception nor non-perception, nor this world nor the next world, neither sun nor moon. It is the cessation of dukkha, unsatisfactoriness. This, bhikkhus, is the unconditioned. — Nibbāna.
For a long time, lord, I have understood the teaching of the Buddha taught thus: Greed, hatred, and delusion should be abandoned.

But, Anuruddha, even though a bhikkhu has abandoned the five lower fetters, he still has with regard to the five aggregates subject to clinging a lingering residual 'I am' conceit, an 'I am' desire, an 'I am' obsession.

There is, bhikkhus, a realm where there is no earth, no water, no fire, no air; no base consisting of the infinity of space, no base consisting of the infinity of consciousness, no base consisting of nothingness, no base consisting of neither-perception-nor-non-perception; neither this world nor the next world, neither moon nor sun. And there, I say, there is neither coming, nor going, nor staying; neither passing away nor arising: unestablished, unevolving, without support [mental object]. This, just this, is the end of dukkha.
For there is no person in the world who is dearer to me than myself. In the same way, there is no person in the world who is dearer to another than himself.
In the past, Bāvarī Vāseṭṭha and Vāseṭṭha the brahmin wandered over and went through all the wrong views, and finally arrived at annihilationism.

Whatever a bhikkhu frequently thinks and ponders upon, that will become the inclination of his mind.
One should not consider the faults of others, nor their doing or not doing good or bad deeds. One should consider only whether one has done or not done good or bad deeds.
From the origination of name-and-form comes the origination of consciousness. The cessation of name-and-form is the cessation of consciousness.

Such is the origin of this whole mass of suffering.

The world is burning with aging and death. The world is burning with sorrow, lamentation, pain, displeasure, and despair.

This, just this, is the end of dukkha.

The thought occurs to me, 'This Dhamma is for one with few desires, not for one with strong desires.' But then it occurs to me, 'Desire is clinging.' With clinging as condition, existence; with existence as condition, birth; with birth as condition, aging and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair come to be. Such is the origin of this whole mass of suffering.
All experiences are preceded by mind, having mind as their master, created by mind.
Hatred is never appeased by hatred in this world. By non-hatred alone is hatred appeased. This is a law eternal.
Do not dwell in the past, do not dream of the future, concentrate the mind on the present moment.
Better than a thousand hollow words, is one word that brings peace.
All that we are is the result of what we have thought. The mind is everything. What we think we become.
To enjoy good health, to bring true happiness to one's family, to bring peace to all, one must first discipline and control one's own mind.
What we think, we become.
As rain falls equally on the just and the unjust, do not burden your heart with judgments but rain your kindness equally on all.
In the sky, there is no distinction of east and west; people create distinctions out of their own minds and then believe them to be true.
If you do not change direction, you may end up where you are heading.
Better than a thousand useless words is one useful word, hearing which one attains peace.
Peace comes from within. Do not seek it without.
You will not be punished for your anger, you will be punished by your anger.
There is no fire like passion; there is no losing throw like hatred; there is no pain like this body; there is no happiness higher than rest.
The greatest prayer is patience.
Happiness does not depend on what you have or who you are. It solely relies on what you think.
Health is the greatest gift, contentment the greatest wealth, faithfulness the best relationship.
He who loves 50 people has 50 woes; he who loves no one has no woes.
What is the appropriate behavior for a man? Whatever befits a dignified person, without conceit, not haughty.
The mind is everything. What you think you become.
To understand everything is to forgive everything.
There is no fear for one whose mind is not filled with desires.
Conquer anger with non-anger. Conquer badness with goodness. Conquer meanness with generosity. Conquer dishonesty with truth.
If you find no one to support you on the spiritual path, walk alone.
There is no path to happiness: happiness is the path.
The only real failure in life is not to be true to the best one knows.
Words have the power to both destroy and heal. When words are both true and kind, they can change our world.
Even as a solid rock is unshaken by the wind, so are the wise unshaken by praise or blame.

Whatever living beings there may be — feeble or strong, long, stout, or of medium size, short, small, large, those seen or those unseen, those dwelling far or near, those who are born as well as those yet to be born — may all beings have happy minds.
Better than a thousand hollow words, is one word that brings peace.
One is not called noble who harms living beings. By not harming living beings one is called noble.
The fool who knows he is a fool is that much wiser. The fool who thinks he is wise is a fool indeed.
Just as a snake sheds its skin, we must shed our past over and over again.
There is no path to happiness: happiness is the path.
By oneself is evil done; by oneself is one defiled. By oneself is evil left undone; by oneself is one made pure. Purity and impurity depend on oneself. No one can purify another.
The greatest gift is to give people your enlightenment, to share it. It has to be the greatest.
Those who are free of resentful thoughts surely find peace.
A jug fills drop by drop.
Neither fire nor wind, birth nor death can erase our good deeds.
To cease from evil, to do good, and to purify the mind yourself, this is the teaching of all the Buddhas.
You will not be punished for your anger, you will be punished by your anger.
All beings are the owners of their actions, heirs to their actions.
Endurance is one of the most difficult disciplines, but it is to the one who endures that the final victory comes.
To be idle is a short road to death and to be diligent is a way of life; foolish people are idle, wise people are diligent.
Just as a solid rock is not shaken by the storm, even so the wise are not affected by praise or blame.
Delight in meditation and solitude. Compose yourself, be happy. You are a seeker.

Whatever living beings there may be — feeble or strong, long, stout, or of medium size, short, small, large, those seen or those unseen, those dwelling far or near, those who are born as well as those yet to be born — may all beings have happy minds.
Work out your own salvation. Do not depend on others.
The tongue like a sharp knife... Kills without drawing blood.
Conquer anger by love, evil by good; conquer the stingy by giving, and the liar by speaking the truth.
One moment can change a day, one day can change a life, and one life can change the world.
You only lose what you cling to.
The wise ones fashioned speech with their thought, sifting it as grain is sifted through a sieve.
Drop by drop is the water pot filled. Likewise, the wise man, gathering it little by little, fills himself with good.
Whatever words we utter should be chosen with care, for people will hear them and be influenced by them for good or ill.
No one saves us but ourselves. No one can and no one may. We ourselves must walk the path.
In separateness lies the world's great misery, in compassion lies the world's true strength.
Silence the angry man with love. Silence the ill-natured man with kindness. Silence the miser with generosity. Silence the liar with truth.
Better than a thousand hollow words, is one word that brings peace.
The fragrance of flowers does not go against the flow of wind; but the perfume of virtues spreads in all directions.
As a solid rock is not shaken by the wind, so the wise are not affected by praise or blame.
The way is not in the sky. The way is in the heart.
If you knew what I know about the power of giving, you would not let a single meal pass without sharing it in some way.
In the sky, there is no distinction of east and west; people create distinctions out of their own minds and then believe them to be true.
We are shaped by our thoughts; we become what we think. When the mind is pure, joy follows like a shadow that never leaves.
The only real failure in life is not to be true to the best one knows.
Speak the truth; yield not to anger; give what you can; never be sparing of kindness.
If with a pure mind a person speaks or acts, happiness follows them like a never-departing shadow.
Whatever harm an enemy may do to an enemy, or a hater to a hater, an ill-directed mind inflicts on oneself a greater harm.
Health is the greatest gift, contentment the greatest wealth, faithfulness the best relationship.
Purity and impurity depend on oneself; no one can purify another.
To understand everything is to forgive everything.
The mind is everything. What you think you become.
If we could see the miracle of a single flower clearly, our whole life would change.
Cease from anger, abandon pride, and do not dwell on past mistakes. Do not seek the faults of others, what they have or have not done.
Just as a mother would protect her only child with her life, even so, let one cultivate a boundless love towards all beings.
Drop by drop is the water pot filled. Likewise, the wise man, gathering it little by little, fills himself with good.
There is no fire like passion; there is no losing throw like hatred; there is no pain like this body; there is no happiness higher than rest.
He who loves 50 people has 50 woes; he who loves no one has no woes.
All experiences are preceded by mind, having mind as their master, created by mind.
To cease from evil, to do good, and to purify the mind yourself, this is the teaching of all the Buddhas.
Better than a thousand hollow words, is one word that brings peace.
Just as a solid rock is not shaken by the wind, so the wise are not affected by praise or blame.
In the sky, there is no distinction of east and west; people create distinctions out of their own minds and then believe them to be true.
The way is not in the sky. The way is in the heart.
The fragrance of flowers does not go against the flow of wind; but the perfume of virtues spreads in all directions.
By oneself is evil done; by oneself is one defiled. By oneself is evil left undone; by oneself is one made pure. Purity and impurity depend on oneself. No one can purify another.
Better than a thousand hollow words, is one word that brings peace.
Speak only endearing speech, speech that is welcomed. Speech, when it brings no evil to others, is a pleasant thing.
By oneself is evil done; by oneself is one defiled. By oneself is evil left undone; by oneself is one made pure. Purity and impurity depend on oneself. No one can purify another.
There is no fire like passion; there is no losing throw like hatred; there is no pain like this body; there is no happiness higher than rest.
Holding on to anger is like grasping a hot coal with the intent of throwing it at someone else; you are the one who gets burned.
Those who are free of resentful thoughts surely find peace.
For hatred does not cease by hatred at any time: hatred ceases by love. This is an unalterable law.
If with a pure mind a person speaks or acts, happiness follows them like a never-departing shadow.
Health is the greatest gift, contentment the greatest wealth, faithfulness the best relationship.
Even death is not to be feared by one who has lived wisely.
Let none find fault with others; let none see the omissions and commissions of others. But let one see one's own acts, done and undone.
Do not dwell in the past, do not dream of the future, concentrate the mind on the present moment.
Just as a mother would protect her only child with her life, even so, let one cultivate a boundless love towards all beings.
In the sky, there is no distinction of east and west; people create distinctions out of their own minds and then believe them to be true.
As a solid rock is not shaken by the wind, so the wise are not affected by praise or blame.
Hatred is never appeased by hatred in this world. By non-hatred alone is hatred appeased. This is a law eternal.
For hate is not conquered by hate: hate is conquered by love. This is a law eternal.
There is no path to happiness: happiness is the path.
Let go of the past, let go of the future, let go of the present, and cross over to the farther shore of existence. With mind wholly liberated, you shall come no more to birth and death.
You will not be punished for your anger, you will be punished by your anger.
To live a pure unselfish life, one must count nothing as one's own in the midst of abundance.
To understand everything is to forgive everything.
An insincere and evil friend is more to be feared than a wild beast; a wild beast may wound your body, but an evil friend will wound your mind.
If we could see the miracle of a single flower clearly, our whole life would change.
Those who have failed to work toward the truth have missed the purpose of living.
To keep the body in good health is a duty... otherwise we shall not be able to keep our mind strong and clear.
To conquer oneself is a greater task than conquering others.
Do not dwell in the past, do not dream of the future, concentrate the mind on the present moment.
There is no fire like passion; there is no losing throw like hatred; there is no pain like this body; there is no happiness higher than rest.
